citation_prediction

Class CitationCore

  • java.lang.Object
    • citation_prediction.CitationCore

  • public class CitationCore
extends java.lang.Object
    For additional information about this source code please visit:
    http://josiahneuberger.github.io/citation_prediction/
    Collaborative Research Project between University of Mary Washington and the Dahlgren Naval Surface Warfare Center.
    Dahlgren Naval Surface Warfare Center
    1. Dr. Jeff Solka
    2. Dr. Allen D. Parks
    3. Computer Scientist Kristen Ash
    University of Mary Washington Faculty:
    1. Dr. Melody Denhere (Math) Supervisor Faculty
    2. Dr. Debra Hydorn (Math)
    3. Dr. Stephen Davies (Computer Science)
    Student Researchers:
    1. William Etcho (Math)
    2. Josiah Neuberger (Computer Science)

    Brief Description:
    This project will explore the concept of predicting future citations based on a citation history of a given paper. The project relies on the initial research of Wang, Song, and Barabasi, which is outlined in their paper titled: "Quantifying Long-Term Scientific Impact" published in "Science 342, 127 (2013)".
    The prediction is based on three different qualities: 1. Preferred attachment 2. Age Decay 3. Fitness

    These three qualities are represented across three variables (The WSB Triple: Wang-Song-Barabási)
    1. (mu) - "indicates immediacy, governing the time for a paper to reach its citation peak (Science pg 128)" 2. (sigma) - "is longevity, capturing the decay rate (Science pg 128)" 3. (lambda) - relative fitness, which is related to '' the paper's fitness which "captures the inherent differences between papers, accounting for the perceived novelty and importance of a discovery. (Science pg 128-129)"

    This Java program will solve the WSB triple by using the general math developed by Dr. Parks to implement the Newton-Raphson method of numeric analysis applied to the three non-linear equations found in the WSB paper. The WSB Triple along with equation #3 on page 129 of the WSB paper will be used to predict future citations of a paper based on a segment of the paper's citation history.

    This class makes use of several packages of the Apache Commons Library (Apache License, V2.0): http://commons.apache.org/
    Specifically:
    Math.Linear (RealMatrix, LUDecomposition, DecompositionSolver, MatrixUtils) Math.Distribution (NormalDistributation: CDF and PDF functions) CSV.CSVRecord CSV.CSVParser Note: the commons.csv package is part of the Sandbox package and therefore is considered in beta with no official releases. this class uses the most recent build to extract data from a tabbed delimited csv file.
    The graphs are all done using the jmathplot library (BSD 3-clause License), which can be found at:
    http://code.google.com/p/jmathplot/

      • graphWSB

        public org.math.plot.Plot2DPanel graphWSB(double[][] data_in_days,
                                 double m,
                                 org.math.plot.Plot2DPanel plot,
                                 java.lang.String graphTitle,
                                 java.lang.String lineLegend,
                                 java.util.ArrayList<java.util.LinkedHashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Double>> wsbSolutions,
                                 boolean showGraph,
                                 javax.swing.JFrame frame)
        This function will take a list of WSB solutions and graph them. You can add solutions to the graph by saving the return of the function the first time and passing it back in on the next call as the 'plot'.
        Parameters:
        data_in_days - The citation data distributed mostly even in days (call fixdata function if data is in years).
        m - The average number of new references in each new paper for a journal.
        plot - The plot you would like the WSB solution plotted to.
        graphTitle - The title to display on the JPanel.
        lineLegend - The title of this curve.
        wsbSolutions - The list of WSB solutions to graph.
        showGraph - Display the graph to the user (generally called once all curves have been added.)
        frame - The frame to display the graph in.
        Returns:
        A Panel containing the graph.

      • printList

        public void printList(java.util.LinkedHashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Double> l)
        This function will print a list containing the calculated values for the Newton-Raphson method in a formated way that is easy to read.
        Parameters:
        l - The list containing the Newton-Raphon calculated values.

      • newtonRaphson

        public java.util.LinkedHashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Double> newtonRaphson(double[][] data,
                                                                       double mu,
                                                                       double sigma,
                                                                       double m)
        This function implements the algorithm designed by Josiah Neuberger and William Etcho used to solve for a WSB solution. The general math for the Newton-Raphson method was provided by Dr. Allen Parks and can be found in the function 'getPartialsData'.

        This algorithm was created under the direction of Supervising University of Mary Washington faculty, Dr. Melody Denhere along with consultation from Dr. Jeff Solka and Computer Scientists Kristin Ash with the Dahlgren Naval Surface Warfare Center.

        If your interested in more information about the research behind this algorithm please visit:
        http://josiahneuberger.github.io/citation_prediction/

        This function uses the following default values:
        Max Iterations = 31
        Parameters:
        data - The citation data in days.
        mu - The initial mu guess to use in the Newton-Raphson method.
        sigma - The initial sigma guess to use in the Newton-Raphson method.
        m - The constant value, which is determined by the average number of references in each new paper for a journal.
        Returns:
        A list containing the WSB solution of (lambda, mu, sigma, iterations).

      • newtonRaphson_ConvergenceTest

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.util.LinkedHashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Double>> newtonRaphson_ConvergenceTest(double[][] data,
                                                                                                            double step,
                                                                                                            double m)
        This function runs the Newton-Raphson function on an interval from .1 to 10 returning a list of all the unique solutions.
        Parameters:
        data - The citation data in days.
        step - The step you would like to use to step through the interval of .1 to 10.
        m - The average number of new references contained in each paper for a journal.
        Returns:
        A list containing the WSB solutions.

        Prints the citation history stored in 'l' in a formated way.
        Parameters:

        header - Headers for columns.

      • getLambda

        public double getLambda(double[][] data,
               double mu,
               double sigma,
               double m,
               double t,
               double n)
        Calculate lambda based on a solution found in the Newton-Raphson method for mu and sigma.
        Parameters:
        data - The citation data in days.
        mu - The solution for mu.
        sigma - The solution for sigma.
        m - The average number of references for new papers for a journal.
        t - The last timestamp for the citation data.
        n - The total number of citations from the citation history.
        Returns:
        The lambda value based on mu and sigma.
